topic.title: ZeroMedium Update 17.12a
topic.body:
### New Features
* You can now use markdown link syntax: `[Link Title](link_address)`
* You can now put space or punctuation after markdown for it to automatically change to visual version. Punctuation includes: . , ! ? ( ) [ ] { }
* You can now add images while editing a story

### Bug Fixes
* Empty responses and stories are *kinda* disallowed (There is still a bug that I'm unsure how to fix)
* The "publish" button is temporarily disabled after clicking it when publishing a response. This prevents people from accidentally clicking it twice, which will post the response twice.
* Images that are uploaded will have the date uploaded appended to the filename. This ensures that there are no collisions with image names.
* For images that are uploaded with non-ascii characters in the filename, the non-ascii characters are removed - this is to prevent a ZeroNet bug with non-latin characters. Spaces are also replaced by underscores and quotes (double and single) are removed.
* The registration will not continue until you select a primary language and enter a username.
* When posting edited story, if title is same as before, no need to add date to end of it
* When interests is empty and you click to follow an interest, do not start the interests string with a comma ','. This prevents there from being an empty interest
http://127.0.0.1:43110/ZeroMedium.bit

topic.title: Small ZeroMedium Update & 18.01 Update
topic.body:
**Small Update**
* Thanks to @putsan for adding Ukrainian (Українська) and Russian (Русский) languages for the topics.
* Added ability to change primary and secondary languages on settings page
* Other small bug fixes

If anyone knows Spanish, It will be helpful if you could translate the topics from the `data/topics.json` file into spanish.

**18.01 Update**
This version is a very small update.
* The "Today's Top Topics" section of the homepage has been updated to be more accurate. The algorithm was also re-implemented in SQL. This should improve it's loading performance (especially on ZeroNet proxies).
* Small bug fixes

The SQL implementation of the "Today's Top Topics" algorithm loads in 1-2 seconds on [ZeroCat proxy](https://zerocat.eu) vs. 4-5 second loading time on that same proxy with the previous JS implementation!

*Note:* You may need to clear your cache for things to update. The current version listed in the footer should say *18.01*.

[/ZeroMedium.bit](/ZeroMedium.bit)

topic.title: Translations Needed for Important Zites
topic.body:
These words/phrases need translated into as many languages as possible for [Important Zites](/1MiS3ud9JogSQpd1QVmM6ETHRmk5RgJn6E):
Important Zites
Categories
All

Description

Language(s)
Enter Tags
Tags
NSFW
Press Enter to Add Tag
Merger-Supported (more info in sidebar, or below on mobile)
Merger Category Name
Submit
Required
Search My Bookmarks
Search My Zites
Search Zites
Search In ... Category // "..." will be replaced with category name
Uploaded by ... // "..." will be replaced with user id
Published by ... // "..." will be replaced with user id
File Size
Date Uploaded
Date Updated
Date Published
Search ...  // "..." will be replaced with site name
... Clones // "..." will be replaced with site name

**Additional Translations:**
There are no merger zites yet!
Update
Created by ... // "..." will be replaced with user id
Submitted by ... // "..." will be replaced with user id

**Notes:**
* Keep the "..." in the translations because I replace them with the words I want to put there and different languages place them in different places. This way, I can place the words that should fit in in the correct place for the respective language.
For example, For "Created by ...", in my code, the "..." gets replaced by the user id. I don't just append the user id but instead replace the "..." with it because one language may need to put the user id in the front or between words. So, I need the translation to put the "..." where the user id would go for that language.
* NSFW means "Not Safe For Work", it's used for porn/adult zites.
* For tags, you press enter - I put this line to translate because of the tags part: "Press Enter to Add Tag".

I'm going to be recreating ZeroMedium, and if people want, I'll record me doing that. This could also help people learn how to make ZeroNet zites. The videos will be uploaded to YouTube and KopyKate.

They won't have a face cam or audio because it's awkward for me to do that.

topic.title: I'm Back!
topic.body:
Hello! School has ended, So I am back and ready to get to work. First things first: Rewriting ZeroMedium completely with a better interface and less bugs - all on video!

Doing this on video will allow new people to see how a zite is created from the ground up, how to use Vue with your zite and the different techniques and weirdness when using it, and my development setup for making and testing zites.

Perhaps I will also write text tutorials that will go along with these videos, we will see. I may also have video on-screen annotations as I will *not* be using my voice.

topic.title: Ways We Can Promote Original Content
topic.body:
I'm wondering, what are the ways we can incentivize or promote original content here on ZeroNet. I think we have enough people for it, and enough zites. We just need people doing it!

Here are some good zites that can be used for original content:
* Videos - KopyKate
* Blogs - ZeroBlog, ZeroMedium
* MicroBlogging/Twitter/Facebook - ZeroMe
* Writing/Essays/Literature - ZeroMedium
* QA (Question-Answer) - ZeroExchange
* Wiki - ZeroWiki, Kiwipedia
* Forums and Discussion - ZeroTalk, ZeroVoat
* Images - the image board zites
* Development - Git Center

Zites we need:
* Podcasting and Music platform dedicated to original content
* Good and Up to date News zites that aren't just mirrors of clearnet stuff
* Goodreads and Review zites

Another thing that I thinks needs to be handled is how people are going to get donations and attributions for their work, because the bitcoin stuff I don't think is working too well (idk).

topic.title: ZeroNet Exe Installer + Beta P2P Message Plugin by @GitCenter
topic.body:
I have created an Exe installer that will do all of these things:
1. Install ZeroNet into Program Files (x86) directory
2. Register ZeroNet with Windows (with a guid)
3. Add shortcuts to ZeroNet, Data directory, and uninstaller in Start Menu
4. Add shortcut to ZeroNet on Desktop
5. Provide option to install some of the plugins that are usually disabled by default.
6. Provide option to install @gitcenter 's new P2P Message Plugin - which you can test with his new [IRC Zite](/1FEL2HhvS48m8SsAPcuyo7irf7J9Ebx449/) - With this new plugin, zites can broadcast messages, which are then distributed throughout the system. These messages are not written to disk, but rather stored in memeory. This also allows the zite owner to determine the timeout for these messages, so that it doesn't have to be 30 seconds. There are more features being worked on, but they are not working yet. **You must have this plugin to use this zite.**
7. Provide option to uninstall. Uninstall will **not** delete your data directory at the moment.

You can download this installer from two places, *Links Updated for v1.3*:
* [GitHub](https://github.com/krixano/ZeroNet-Windows-Exe-Installer/releases/latest)
* [ZeroUp Unlimited](/1CiXRY9ATZSoZqBzwMfXEMsKtPRt2aQoF2/data/users/12gAes6NzDS9E2q6Q1UXrpUdbPS6nvuBPu/1526910122-ZeroNetInstaller.exe)

After installation, you can move over your data directory by replacing the data directory of the new installation. You can get to the data directory of the new installation by clicking `ZeroNet/Data directory` in the start menu.

This installer will be updated from time to time.

topic.title: Moving from GitHub to GitCenter
topic.body:
With the recent Microsoft acquisition of GitHub, some people may be wanting to move their GitHub repos to Git Center. This will show as a guide (in addition to the guide within GitCenter) on how you can push your existing repos to Git Center. Any questions regarding the move and any problems during it can be asked here.

**If you want to keep GitHub remote and add remote for GitCenter alongside**

1.) Create a new GitCenter repo

2.) `git remote add gitcenter [path to merger zite folder/name.git]` - Add GitCenter as a remote.
You can get the name and address of the folder by clicking the clone button on your repo page. This clone button should give something like:
`git clone $path_to_data\1BEPbMfV8QtaZCD2cPNbabfDKnmhTAZRPx/zeromedium.git`.

The part you need is `$path_to_data\1BEPbMfV8QtaZCD2cPNbabfDKnmhTAZRPx/zeromedium.git`. You just need to replace `$path_to_data` with the path to the ZeroNet data folder (for people who use my ZeroNet installer, it should be something similar to `C:\Program Files (x86)\ZeroNet\ZeroNet\data`).

3.) `git push gitcenter --force` - Force push to GitCenter repo. This will overwrite what's in the git center repo with your repo. This is needed if the two repos are different (which they are if you created new GitCenter repo and your pushing an existing repo to it). You'll only need to do this the first push. All subsequent pushes will work without `--force`.

---
**If you want to replace GitHub remote with GitCenter (just one additional step)**

1.) Create a new GitCenter repo

2.) `git remote remove origin` - Remove the GitHub origin remote

3.) `git remote add origin [path to merger zite folder/name.git]` - Add GitCenter as the origin remote.
You can get the name and address of the folder by clicking the clone button on your repo page. This clone button should give something like:
`git clone $path_to_data\1BEPbMfV8QtaZCD2cPNbabfDKnmhTAZRPx/zeromedium.git`. 

The part you need is `$path_to_data\1BEPbMfV8QtaZCD2cPNbabfDKnmhTAZRPx/zeromedium.git`. You just need to replace `$path_to_data` with the path to the ZeroNet data folder (for people who use my ZeroNet installer, it should be something similar to `C:\Program Files (x86)\ZeroNet\ZeroNet\data`).

4.) `git push --force` - Force push to GitCenter repo. This will overwrite what's in the git center repo with your repo. This is needed if the two repos are different (which they are if you created new GitCenter repo and your pushing an existing repo to it). You'll only need to do this the first push. All subsequent pushes will work without `--force`.

@gitcenter

topic.title: ZeroNet Windows Installer v1.4 & Beta Release of KxoNetwork
topic.body:
### Update ZeroNet Windows Installer v1.4
You can get the new version here: [https://github.com/krixano/ZeroNet-Windows-Exe-Installer/releases/tag/1.4](https://github.com/krixano/ZeroNet-Windows-Exe-Installer/releases/tag/1.4)
* Ability to choose an existing ZeroNet Data Directory to move over to new installation.
* Updated ZeroNet
* Updated optional PeerMessage and BackgroundMessage Plugins
* Bug Fixes

*Problems:*
* Disabled tray icon because ZeroNet doesn't currently start up with enabled
* Updating ZeroNet will re-add/re-enable the Tray Icon plugin
* Tor (and meek bridges) may not be packaged with this

### Beta Release of [KxoNetwork](/1GTVetvjTEriCMzKzWSP9FahYoMPy6BG1P)
* Note that it is still WIP and not everything is working. What is currently working is listed below.
* Create a KxoId - the first Id provider with id uniqueness without requiring the use of the clearnet **You must have @imachug's PeerMessage plugin to register an id**! (You can get this plugin with my ZeroNet installer above, or from [GitHub](https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/Plugin-PeerMessage)). A rough explanation of how this works is given on the registration page as well as how zite owners can support this new id provider.
* *Very quickly* search Zites from ZeroSites, 0List, and Important Zites (as well as repos from Git Center)
  - Additional zites and functionality will be added very soon.
  - A bug fix for duplicate listings will also be coming out soon.
* If question detected from search query (starting with question word - English only - or ending with question mark), the most relevant ZeroExchange question will show up at the bottom

**Plans for KxoNetwork:**
* Integrate all the CORS searching that Important Zites already has, plus more - including adding custom zites to search (Important Zites will remain one of the backends for this searching)
* Portal for all of my Zites that will utilize KxoId as well as partnering zites (more on this later).
* A zite suitable to be used as a homepage for ZeroNet
* Advanced searching

**Plans for Important Zites:**
* Important Zites will be rebranded and will act like the backend for zite searching from the KxoNetwork zite.
* Bookmarks and Bookmark categories will be retained, but expanded to allow for bookmarks from the other search backends (including ZeroSites and 0list).

topic.title: KxoHub
topic.body:
ZeroMe hub for KxoId's, with support for PeakId, CryptoId, ZeroId, and KaffieId also.

* ZeroId - 488.28125 KiB

topic.title: KxoVid
topic.body:
KxoVid is a Video Sharing Zite I started around 5-6 months ago to try to mimic and improve upon both YouTube for Clearnet and other existing ZeroNet video sharing zites. Features:

* Modern Smooth Design with Dark Theme (via ZeroNet theme settings on ZeroHello)
* Relevance-based searching
* **Optional** Chromecast support (only available on Chrome)
* Category Merger Zites
* Subscriptions
* Multiple Channels per user
* Customizable Channel Pages
* Category Channels
* [KxoId](/1GTVetvjTEriCMzKzWSP9FahYoMPy6BG1P/?/create-id) support (KxoId now up-and-running again)

### And Now, It officially supports ZeroId!

**What's Next?**
* Thumbnails! (with option to disable)
* Playlists
* Autoplay setting
* Likes - Recommend a video to your subscribers
* Subscriptions show up in ZeroHello NewsFeed
* Mentions in Comments show up in NewsFeed
* Follow Video Comments
* Improved Video Player

http://127.0.0.1:43110/14c5LUN73J7KKMznp9LvZWkxpZFWgE1sDz

topic.title: Feedback for KxoVid
topic.body:
I'm working on KxoVid again. I'm already aware of KxoVid problems with Icons in Tor Browser (and some proxies apparently, although not all, which makes me suspect it's a proxy issue). I also am already planning on adding Playlists, Watch Later, Likes, Thumbnails, a better homepage design, Asciinema support, and improving the Chromecasting feature.

I would like to get Feedback for anything else that users may want or need, including Bugs and Features.

http://127.0.0.1:43110/kxovid.bit

topic.title: What I've Done Thus Far
topic.body:
## What I've Done

**Zites**
* [KxoId](/kxonet.bit/?/create-id) - KxoId's accepted by KxoVid and [0Play Game Center](/1Ag6xidDHiPgWoDKhfSx4xFQr6WC3NqxZg/) (by @gitcenter)
* [KxoNetwork](/kxonet.bit) - Portal to all of my zites. Search Important Zites db and other zites using CORS. Plugin Store. KxoId Registration.
* [KxoVid](/kxovid.bit) - Video Sharing Zite
* [ZeroMedium](/zeromedium.bit) - Medium for ZeroNet - a place to post stories, essays, writings, etc.
* [ZeroExchange](/ZeroExchange.bit) - QA Zite with Topic merger zites.
* [Important Zites (new)](/1MiS3ud9JogSQpd1QVmM6ETHRmk5RgJn6E/) - Zite index with search and categories. Also, a search (using CORS) for various other zites including ZeroTalk (and some clones), ZeroMe, 0List, ZeroSites, and others.
* [Important Zites Old](/15Pf9VVuDT8NSWj1qUBh4V89yPmrmzRw6a/) - My very first zite. A zite index of what I thought were the most important zites, all organized by categories. Later added a search with the help of @glightstar (creator of [ThunderWave](/thunderwave.bit/))
* [ZeroNet Dev Center](/DevCenter.bit) - 3 tutorials (by me) on ZeroNet development for users and programmers, and one tutorial by @lola on ZeroNet Plugin development.
* [ZeroDb](/ZeroDB.bit/) - A dbschema builder for databases for zites. Unfinished.
* [New ZeroWiki](/1LX2wiouHctuUXtu5WkVM9TJJ3YoL6gAfm/) - A clone of ZeroWiki where I reorganized stuff.
* Decentralized Searching (I sometimes call it "Peer Searching") Demo zite that utilizes the [PeerMessage plugin](https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/Plugin-PeerMessage) (by @gitcenter) - unreleased.

**My ZeroNet Related Projects and Libraries**
* [ZeroNet Gopher Plugin](https://github.com/imachug/Plugin-Gopher) (github) - worked on this with @gitcenter
* [ZeroFrame Router](https://github.com/krixano/ZeroFrame-Router) (github) with VueJS plugin - A dynamic js router that works with ZeroNet. Vuejs plugin to make it work with vuejs. See [this tutorial](/1Jw72CWtFuYiGkCnWxXMdAkwtFLMa21XmG/?/posts/zeronet-with-create-react-app-and-basic-routing-using-zeroframe-router_p2) on how to get it to work with React.
* Searching Library - used for the searching of some of my zites, including KxoVid, Important Zites, ZeroMedium, ZeroExchange, and KxoNetwork. This is also what powers the "Related Videos" sidebar on KxoVid.
* [ZeroNet-Win-Exe-Installer](https://github.com/krixano/ZeroNet-Windows-Exe-Installer) - A graphical installer for ZeroNet on Windows. Hasn't been updated in a while - I may get to this soon.
* ZeroQuery - js library to making db queries easier. Unfinished.
* ZeroGraph - was going to be OpenGraph for ZeroNet. Unfinished.

## What I did While Away

During the 4 months that I was away, I worked on other projects unrelated to ZeroNet:
* Involved in the Gopher and Pubnix Communities
* EdimCoder updates
* Started some new projects - text-based sandbox game, terminal document reader
* Wrote a lot on my Gopherhole

## What's Next?
These are just the things I have planned so far:

* KxoVid Updates
* Get KxoId up and running again and start accepting trusted nodes
* Platform - a new zite I'll be working on
* ZeroNet Gopher - get this plugin up and running and working with Python 3
* Finish ZeroExchange

## Support Me

You can support me by donating to either: 
* My bitcoin address: 12gAes6NzDS9E2q6Q1UXrpUdbPS6nvuBPu
* [My patreon](https://patreon.com/krixano)

However, I ask that you consider donating to [@Kaffie first](https://www.patreon.com/aprilc0t).

topic.title: Promoting Ivanq/GitCenter's Zites
topic.body:
... because they are too good to not have users!
* [CodeR](/1CodEr7T9xNXSPcwbsvf5fHTqsixDMwDzL/) - One of the first zites he created. ZeroNet alternative to JSFiddle and CodePen.
* [GitCenter](/1GitLiXB6t5r8vuU2zC6a8GYj9ME6HMQ4t/) - GitHub alternative to ZeroNet
* [Kiwipedia](/1KiwiBCVBUcuypVm8FEmUW9YT6fJDXkN9r/) - Wikipedia alternative. Allows user to import directly from Wikipedia or update article on Kiwipedia with latest Wikipedia article.
* [0Play Game Center](/1Ag6xidDHiPgWoDKhfSx4xFQr6WC3NqxZg) - Uses PeerMessage plugin ([you can download this here](/kxonet.bit/?/plugins)) to create a P2P gaming platform - currently has Chess (kinda buggy atm) and Tic Tac Toe (which *does* work). Also has lobby chat where the messages are sent instantly (due to use of PeerMessage) and in-game chat.
* [ZPlace](/1D6f2CvDRhPeEeBAcmqGt3X9z2CkLpmv2V/) - Uses PeerMessage plugin. Clone of Reddit's 'Place' game.

Ivanq/GitCenter/Imachug is also the creator of the PeerMessage plugin, btw.

topic.title: ZeroExchange Now Becomes KxoQA
topic.body:
I have release an update to ZeroExchange - which is now called KxoQA. KxoQA is a Question-Answer zite for many different topics. It uses merger zites for topics. If you don't see a topic you need/want, you can clone one of the default topics and it'll be available through the interface. Email me the address of the topic so that I can put it on the index (this process will be improved later).

* Proper About Page
* Rebranding from ZeroExchange to KxoQA
* See answers and comments to your questions from ZeroHello NewsFeed
* See comments to your answers from ZeroHello NewsFeed
* KxoId support
* Optimization and bug fixes (no need to reload page when clicking on topic from sidebar)
* The ZeroNet topic is now the default topic downloaded automatically on first startup.

http://127.0.0.1:43110/1PHBjZSAc6mHDMkySJNs3XeSXUL7eY7Q7W

36_19sggoAZ4hcorrrfWoFWP9rwfpVsL29cnZ.body: Hi. I'm the creator of this Zite. I want to add that this Zite isn't fully complete yet. I still have ideas that I would like to explore. One of these Ideas is the ability to vote up Zite Requests, and once a Zite Request gets enough votes, it will be added to the main list. You can visit the [Github page](https://github.com/krixano/ImportantZites) to see more of my future plans and help out if you like by creating Issues or Pull Requests. All contributions are welcome!

1_1Mpr8B1fRGBctzf7g9a6X1cb4WbQULH92N.body:
I have a basic tutorial on my [ZeroNet Dev Center](/14pM9huTYzJdyQyHRj6v2kfhMe8DrxwpGt) zite here: [/14pM9huTYzJdyQyHRj6v2kfhMe8DrxwpGt/?/tutorials/the_basics](/14pM9huTYzJdyQyHRj6v2kfhMe8DrxwpGt/?/tutorials/the_basics)
Currently, it mostly tells you the very basics *before* you start creating a zite, like how zites are updated and sent to peers, how they are kept secure using Digital Signatures, etc. Although it does cover cloning a zite, and how to create an empty zite. I will eventually have more tutorials on there. There's also a place to ask Development Questions and get answers.

3_1Ho48cxWwRFdDChHksp1fhdPvGmpaiZfcH.body: I head that this was fake, but I don't know.

I am fine with this as long as they don't *censor* things. They have never said anything about *censoring* it as far as I know. According to the article I provided below (*which comes directly from Mozilla*), it just looks like they are investing in creating software to fact check things, teaching people about misinformation, and helping fund other misinformation-combatting projects: https://blog.mozilla.org/blog/2017/08/08/mozilla-information-trust-initiative-building-movement-fight-misinformation-online/
Furthermore, as far as I can tell, they haven't said they are teaming up with George Soros - this "fact" is coming from sources other than Mozilla themselves.

So, just be careful where you get your information. Like I have said, I don't know if this is true or not, but according to what I have read *directly from Mozilla*, they make no mention of George Soros or of *censoring* things in the future.

> [kmueller](#comment_57_1PvReUtzc5s92BWTUDnxvmVGepNcyA2otB): ADL

I have search for a bit and so far have found no information (including from Mozilla) stating they have partnered with CTR or ADL. To go a step further, Mozilla promotes *Free Choice*, Open Source and Open Internet, Net Neutrality, and Decentralization (as in spreading the market out) - the first of which seems to conflict with your argument about Mozilla.

You are also presupposing that CTR and ADL are liars, slanderers, and communists. Obviously I don't know about the first two, however, I don't think that wanting to stop hate speech and terrorism are related to communism - I may be wrong.

If you are not going to argue using *facts* and *reputable **and direct** sources*, then I am going to be done with this argument. If you are willing to provide these *facts* and *reputable **and direct** sources*, then **I am interested in seeing them.**

> [kmueller](#comment_58_1PvReUtzc5s92BWTUDnxvmVGepNcyA2otB): They are liars slanderers and commies, well marxists actually. And they have no interest in stopping hate speech and terrorist. They just want to shut down what they think is offensive like calling trannies "he" instead of "she" or "xir", this happened recently with the node.js project. [...]

I just read the article you linked. I do agree that you shouldn't have to think about diversity, you should just have to think about who are good programmers, etc. If they end up being diverse, then so be it - but it isn't necessarily racists when there's a person of color or different sexual orientation that you didn't think did a good job with the code, etc. However, I'm not sure that there are or aren't biased people who hire certain people as programmers over others because of their biases. It'd be something that I'd have to research further.

I've also never heard of anything like what was detailed in the article (with the github message about not accepting pull requests from people of color). I just can't believe that that has actually happened. It's sad that people just automatically jump to conclusions with no substantial proof, just imagining a pattern from something they observed. And the thing is, these patterns that people assume out of observations are often wrong - This is precisely why Scientists don't just look at patterns. They conduct multiple experiments and modify hypotheses and theories until they know for sure. I think many people need to work on this more.

> [darkshroud](#comment_7_1BQaDuyXqze4tNXucqvbz3yUVkysxCoeni): https://www.brave.com/ [...]

I am actually using brave for mobile right now. But for my laptop, I use Firefox because of the Nightly version - I don't know if derivatives of Firefox (palemoon, etc) have a nightly version. I use the Nightly version because it has the new parallelized css styling engine that's written in Rust. I'm now just waiting for their new rendering engine to come out - I think it's called Webrender (or Quantum Render).

> [kmueller](#comment_61_1PvReUtzc5s92BWTUDnxvmVGepNcyA2otB): The people who do not hire certain people despite their qualification are in the absolute minority if they exist at all. CS is not a field where you can be picky with the look of your employees as those are already rare enough as they are. [...]

How about instead of being rude, you actually read what I said correctly. Looks like I will have to do it for you:
> I've also never heard of anything like what was detailed in the article (with the github message about not accepting pull requests from people of color). I just can't believe that that has actually happened. It's sad that people just automatically jump to conclusions with no substantial proof, just imagining a pattern from something they observed.
Here, I was clearly (or at least I thought) talking about what was detailed in the article. The person who made the comment on github "jump[ed] to conclusions with no substantial proof". I wasn't talking about you (or the person who wrote the article)! And when I said `I just can't believe that that has actually happened.`, I wasn't being literal. `I just can't believe` is a figure of speech meaning I *was surprised* to hear that something like this happened. It's used all the time like this.

Now, I realize in hindsight that it was a little ambiguous, but guess what? How about you ask what I meant instead of *jumping to the conclusion* that I was talking about you! 

Also, you can be a little bit more polite considering not everyone is going to agree with you, and you have to deal with that. Opinions are what make people different, there isn't necessarily anything wrong with that. Notice how I was much more polite considering I didn't necessarily agree with some of your arguments, etc. Life is too short to be spewing hateful speech about or being rude to other people who may have very good reasons for their opinions. Just think about it. Anyways, hope you have a fine day.

> [kmueller](#comment_66_1PvReUtzc5s92BWTUDnxvmVGepNcyA2otB): Isnt Palemoon open source?Just fork it and remove the code that causes this. [...]

It's fine. I realize that people have moods, people misunderstand things, etc. etc.

> [l0bster](#comment_1_1FcMuJwqkSPP7C3gnNLugZGwwSGpugX2rA): Good idea. But cant login. Link to Sing in dont active.

Have you visited the site before. If you clicked the signin before and clicked to login but didn't complete the registration, it will do that. Also, if you're account was already selected but you didn't go through the registration process, it will also do this (I am aware of these particular issues and am still trying to figure out how to fix it - this is also why I haven't added the ability to change user yet). What you could do is, *while on the zite*:
1. Slide to the left the 0 button in the top right corner
2. Under identity address, click change
3. Click "Unique to site"
4. Drag the 0 button back to the right
5. Click the signin button again. This time you should get a signin box. After you click the signin button and select your account, you will be prompted to type in a name.

If you are still not being prompted for a name, or the signin box that I mention above doesn't show up, please send me anything that is printed in the console when you click the Signin button (open the "developer tools", Ctrl-Shift-I for Firefox, click the 'console' tab).

You can post in other languages right now, but I will be adding things in the future that will filter out only the stories for your selected languages (notice the plural, you will be able to select multiple languages to use/see, it will be a profile setting).

> [iyogo887vyg87oy8](#comment_23_1H5UJ7LneToGqYqJ9fbLnu1Ko2pxTpchof): Yep I think it's a weird thing with Esperanto that its community is bothered about the language itself, as opposed to say how English speakers think of English. IDK I think maybe we could get over this if we were native Esperantists or maybe it's just a unique thing to Esperanto with it being an invention in of itself, much like an iPhone or a car, which people never shut about. I'd like to see non-esperanto things discussed in esperanto so we can use the language instead of obsessing over it lol.

Learning esperanto isn't really a waste of time. Sure, there may not be as many people speaking it as natural languages. But there are other benefits to learning it other than the ability to converse with people who speak it. This is true for any language.

> [rrwtbrsyq8wmackv](#comment_21_1PrxUQFugjmputGP2FzPSw4Wmq6tCd7xV7): If it's true for any language, why not learn a language that also lets you speak to millions?  (When I say "speak" here and in other posts, of course I really mean "communicate with", whether it's out loud or via internet forums or paper mail or whatever.) [...]

There are many benefits to learning *any* language. However, some languages are easier to learn than others. Some languages have much in common with other languages, therefore making those other languages easier to learn if you wanted to learn a third language. Some languages expand your mental idea's/state by being more different semantically, grammatically, and pragmatically than your native language. There are many others. Esperanto hits many of these.

Here's an experiment that was done with Esperanto. One group took french for 4 years. The other group took Esperanto for the first 2-3 years, then took french for the last year(s). Which one knew more French? The second group.

Esperanto lets you get the benefits of speaking another language in less time. After learning Esperanto, it also allows you to learn other languages that would be more useful (because of their higher numbers in speakers) in less time.

However, this is most likely true with languages that are similar to Esperanto: languages that take words from various other languages, that have relatively consistent grammars, and that are easy to remember grammatically, such as Ido and Universal.

I'm also of the opinion that you shouldn't learn a language based on how many people speak it, because chances are you aren't going to be speaking to that many people. The amount of people that speak *any* language isn't a detriment to the language, there's always people to talk to.

You should learn a language based on it's cognitive benefits and your interest in it, including literature, history, grammar (if you are like me and like grammar), etc. You will have a better time learning it.

> [heyjude](#comment_6_1Ka5KfU2RbHEMTkHPPjAuiYCPbbxAtcoSn): Bullshit my man, somewhere around to 10 million people talk esperanto. Now let's look at french: 274 millions.Only difference is one group are pseudo-intellectual faggot while the other is an ethno-linguistic group, which pseudo intellectual faggots tend not to like.

How exactly does that relate to what I said?

btw, you're using the word "faggot" wrong.

> [rrwtbrsyq8wmackv](#comment_22_1PrxUQFugjmputGP2FzPSw4Wmq6tCd7xV7): That's an interesting study I didn't know about, and I'd be curious to know more about the setting and experiment design.  Can you share a reference?  I'm particularly curious about things like: [...]

According to the study described, Esperanto helps you learn many languages faster. Why, because you already learned one language: Esperanto. It is very well know that learning a third language is faster than learning the second because you have already learned a language before (the second). This, in fact, extends to many other things besides languages.

Next, Esperanto borrows *many* words from European and slavic, languages as well as Greek and Latin, meaning words are very similar (libro in Esperanto is book, libro in Spanish is book). You can then more easily learn these words in Esperanto if the language in which the word was borrowed from is your native language, or a language you learned previously. These are called *cognates*. Esperanto has many with many other languages, including English (). Again, very well know as this exists in other languages, but I would say less so in languages that come from different language families (English as an exception because a lot of Latin came into English around the time of Middle English, and then again after that - I haven't read on this for a while, so I may be wrong about the *times* that latin came into English).

Esperanto has a pretty consistent grammar. This means there are less exceptions, decreasing the time you must take to learn these exceptions, and the ease in which you can learn and remember the grammar of the language. Languages, including Esperanto, that have pretty consistens grammars take less time to learn and are generally (at least slightly) easier to learn because of less exceptions and "weirdness" within the language.

What I was mainly saying was that the amount of speakers isn't a limiting factor because even the amount of Esperanto speakers is enough to be able to read a lot of material and speak to a lot of people. You aren't going to speak to more than 10 million people in your lifetime. Same goes to literature but less so, of course (also dependent on how much you read).

Learning Esperanto is also useful for people who want to study constructed languages, their cultures, their people, beliefs. It's also might be useful for Linguists and conlangers (me being one myself).

Languages have many cognitive benefits, yes. Not necessarily with the vocab. They strengthen your brain. They allow you to more easily learn another language. They allow you to learn how to learn a language more effectively, which will improve how you learn your third language. They let you become more exposed to a more variety of cultures, ideas, etc. It improves memory, your native-language skills, etc. It makes you more aware about the specifics of languages (grammar - all languages more or less have very similar things within them, there's also different types of languages, for example inflectional, isolating - each having similar things when looking at morphology and syntax - you should look more into linguistics if you're interested in languages).

But also, there are different Semantics and Pragmatics in different langauges. Different languages categorize or differentiate between things differently. In English there is here, there, and afar - they distinguish between distance (here is closer than there). But in other languages, there may be more words with more differences in distances. Look into Semantics and Pragmatics if you want.

For the study, there were many studies done: [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Esperanto#Third-language_acquisition](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Esperanto#Third-language_acquisition). I know that people don't trust Wikipedia, but it does give sources. Here's an exerpt:

> Studies have been conducted in New Zealand,[75] United States,[76][77][78] Germany,[79] Italy[80] and Australia.[81] The results of these studies were favorable and demonstrated that studying Esperanto before another foreign language expedites the acquisition of the other, natural language. This appears to be because learning subsequent foreign languages is easier than learning one's first foreign language, whereas the use of a grammatically simple and culturally flexible auxiliary language like Esperanto lessens the first-language learning hurdle. In one study,[82] a group of European secondary school students studied Esperanto for one year, then French for three years, and ended up with a significantly better command of French than a control group, who studied French for all four years.

This also talks about the study I just mentioned to you in the previous post, here's the reference: 
> Williams, N. (1965) 'A language teaching experiment', Canadian Modern Language Review 22.1: 26–28

> [rrwtbrsyq8wmackv](#comment_23_1PrxUQFugjmputGP2FzPSw4Wmq6tCd7xV7): I guess everyone has different goals when learning a language, but I suspect most people either want to communicate with others in the foreign language or else access the literature and other cultural materials in that language.  The number of people that speak it (and for how long it's been spoken) are pretty directly related to these goals.  Esperanto is a bad bet on both counts.  If you know of any actual data on why people learn the foreign languages they do, I'd be interested to read it. [...]

Now for what I like about Esperanto:
* Very easy to learn
* Learn more in a week than in 1 year of Spanish (based on experience, I took 3 years of Spanish in school, but only after a few weeks a learning Esperanto, I could speak more than in Spanish after 1 year)
* Less exceptions to remember (especially compared to all those root-changing rules in Spanish, ex: o->ue; dormir -> duermo)
* Constructed
* Interesting way it handles grammar in a simplified way
* Its correlatives system
* Takes words from many languages
* and more that I don't want to take the time to write out

15_16NS3rBdW9zpLmLSQoD8nLTtNVsRFtVBhd.body: I thought instant apps were completely different from progressive web apps. I think what your talking about is PWAs (the "Add to Homescreen" functionality), not Instant Apps.

> [obiwanzanobi](#comment_55_1LUy9iAxeWsj1DP5L8V17Yb2vo87FucjgD): sounds more like glorified bookmarks.

Kinda. PWAs, which I'm pretty sure is what he is talking about, run in a separate window without any bars at the top and so far, Opera and Chrome work with them. However, Microsoft has already started work on integrating them with their Windows Store, and firefox is also working on implementing them. The also are designed so the web app shows a screen as soon as possible, then download everything else when needed.

However, Instant Apps are completely different. They are a refactoring of Android Apps into modules. Then, the minimum required modules to make the app work and as light as possible are downloaded quickly to make the app appear "instantly". Hence, *Instant* Apps because you don't have to download them, you can try a lightweight version before you do.

> [styromaniac](#comment_129_16NS3rBdW9zpLmLSQoD8nLTtNVsRFtVBhd): The behavior is identical for shortcuts made with Chromium. [...]

Hold on, I think I know what your saying. Your saying Instant Apps are like PWAs, but for android apps right? I guess that comparison makes sense, but there's pretty big differences under the hood, PWAs being web apps while Instant Apps being modulated Android Apps. I originally thought you were saying that Instant Apps is the "Add to Homescreen" stuff. Then I noticed the "It's identical if ..." part, which suggests analogy.

> [styromaniac](#comment_130_16NS3rBdW9zpLmLSQoD8nLTtNVsRFtVBhd): I don't really know what PWAs are. What I know is these instant apps show no difference to Chromium shortcuts. [...]

PWAs are the web apps that can be added to your homescreen. They also load progressively, meaning they show a screen instantly, then load things when needed rather than trying to load it all at startup/pageload.

Instant Apps, like I said before, are Android Apps. This means they don't use web technologies, they use Java and the Android Development Kit, etc. They are also contained in APKs, just like normal Android apps. The difference between android apps and instant apps are that instant apps are android apps that have been refactored into modules. This allows google to download only the modules that are needed for the app to run in a *lightweight* mode before you need to install them. You then install them to get the full functionality.

Biggest difference, PWAs use a browser and use web technologies and can be available for all platforms (Microsoft is working to get them into their store, Firefox is working on implementing them, I'm not sure what Apple is going to do with them), Instant Apps don't and are only for Android because they are Android Apps.

> [styromaniac](#comment_131_16NS3rBdW9zpLmLSQoD8nLTtNVsRFtVBhd): Instant apps I've used behave and look exactly like PWAs.

Yes they behave similarly. But they are not the same. They are **android apps**. PWAs are **Web Apps**. You can also *install* Instant apps, you can't with PWAs. And Instant Apps are only for Android, pwas will be available soon for more platforms than just Android.

ZeroNet zites would work with PWAs, but not with Instant Apps because that would require they become android apps. The only thing we need to make zites into PWAs is service worker support. I actually made an issue on ZeroNet's github about this: https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/issues/1065

Twitter Lite is a PWA, not an Instant App. The websites that act as apps and allow you to add them to the homescreen are PWAs. 

But yes, we can use PWAs for Zites, but we need service worker support. However, I don't know how it would work when zites are put into iframes.
The thing I said about the modules doesn't apply to Twitter Lite, because the modules are only for Instant Apps, and Twitter Lite is a PWA.

> [styromaniac](#comment_133_16NS3rBdW9zpLmLSQoD8nLTtNVsRFtVBhd): Understood. Now let's address whether we can do this with zites.

I edited my comment from before you posted this. Here's what I said:

But yes, we can use PWAs for Zites, but we need service worker support. However, I don't know how it would work when zites are put into iframes.
I made an issue on ZeroNet's github about this: https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/issues/1065

> [styromaniac](#comment_134_16NS3rBdW9zpLmLSQoD8nLTtNVsRFtVBhd): I believe I've heard from nofish that putting zites into iframes isn't possible.

That's how it works now doesn't it? He puts zites into iframes so he can get the sidebar thing, and so the zite can't do anything outside of the iframe.

If you view the page source, it shows an iframe:

```
<!-- Site Iframe -->
<iframe src='about:blank' id='inner-iframe' sandbox="allow-forms allow-scripts allow-top-navigation allow-popups "></iframe>
```
The problem is the zite inside the iframe needs to talk to a service worker in order to do certain things. Also, I believe service workers are required for PWAs.

In the github issue, I say that if he can't make the zite in the iframe talk to the service worker, he might just be able to add an empty service worker that way we can at the very least add the zite to the homescreen (he'd also need to add settings in the content.json file for the other PWA options).

> [schoolkopykate](#comment_1_15ubGEWWQSXH6Xp1Lg5JcTqMrKVm51BVkg): Just fixed a big ass bug. Video URL router now uses the [certificate user id] + [video date added] in order to link to a video. [...]

That's an interesting way to handle that. What I do with my zites is to have the id's unique, but only for that user (so many users could have something with an id of 1, but we can still refer to it by using both the auth_address and the id) and remove the "PRIMARY KEY AUTOINCREMENT" so the id's aren't unique globally and so they don't change per client. Then, the only thing to solve is to have the id's increment, which can be done by storing the next_id in the json file and incrementing that whenever you add a new field to the json file. Then, you just use it as the id when the user posts the next item.

Your way is quicker (and perhaps better) because you don't have to mess with trying to find the next id and storing that (which involves either another table or the keyvalue table).

5_17H8EGEoNF1z2AXFtXmBQJLHTmh7gMGzzS.body: The problem is the zites have to be able to access the files in order to show them on the zite. Can zites access your computer from outside their own directories?

> [realkittykate](#comment_40_17H8EGEoNF1z2AXFtXmBQJLHTmh7gMGzzS): well.. considering how the client is running on your computer, I would assume it should be able to access files outside of zeronet.. i.e. ../../../My_Custom_Big_Files_Folder/data/users/xxxxxxxxxxxxx/this.mp4

Not the client, the zite. Also, the user's content.json needs to be able to know which files are optional so that other clients know this (and so it can get the hash of the files).

> [realkittykate](#comment_40_17H8EGEoNF1z2AXFtXmBQJLHTmh7gMGzzS): well.. considering how the client is running on your computer, I would assume it should be able to access files outside of zeronet masterseed folder.. i.e. ../../../My_Custom_Big_Files_Folder/xxxxx/data/users/xxxxxxxxxxxxx/this.mp4

Currently, zites can simply link to the file based on a relative link going into the user's folder. But if we move the files, it will no longer work, which means we need to be able to ask ZeroNet for the directory path of the file, which would mean yet another command. And that's assuming zites are allowed to access anything on the computer, which I don't know if ZeroNet has protections against this.

> [realkittykate](#comment_41_17H8EGEoNF1z2AXFtXmBQJLHTmh7gMGzzS): Couldn't this be relative to each individual user's client, though?

Okay, so for example, I have an optional file stored in my user's directory. The zite can access it by going to `data/users/[my auth address]/file.ext`. When someone download's the optional file, the zite will just use this url because it's relative to the zite and it's always located in the same place. But if we start moving files around, we instead have to ask the ZeroNet client where the file was moved to because everyone could move it to different places.

> [krixano](#comment_106_12gAes6NzDS9E2q6Q1UXrpUdbPS6nvuBPu): Okay, so for example, I have an optional file stored in my user's directory. The zite can access it by going to data/users/[my auth address]/file.ext. When someone download's the optional file, the zite will just use this url because it's relative to the zite and it's always located in the same place. But if we start moving files around, we instead have to ask the ZeroNet client where the file was moved to because everyone could move it to different places.

We also have to be able to write to the correct/desired directory upon upload of a file. And, when the user's content.json file is signed, we have to check that desired directory for files that the user uploaded to their data directory so we can get the file listing and hashes.

> [realkittykate](#comment_42_17H8EGEoNF1z2AXFtXmBQJLHTmh7gMGzzS): I suppose there should be a way to set up some automatic symbolic linking system.

I didn't think of that. That would probably be the easiest solution without having to require a lot of changes in ZeroNet client, including potentially breaking changes for zites. You can probably write a plugin for this.

> [realkittykate](#comment_43_17H8EGEoNF1z2AXFtXmBQJLHTmh7gMGzzS): I'm also a big confused as to how the Optional big file settings work.. seeding part of the file. [...]

[...]

Why would you have to manage the missing big files? You don't need those big files on *every* device you use. If you want just necessary files, then don't use big files. It doesn't make it more complicated, it's literally the same as it was before big file support as long as you don't use the big files. 

And I also don't know why it would matter whether the big files are in your users directory if their optional. Putting them there allows the sites to actually show/use the files relative to their root, and in the same place.

1512159205_1NpjJ6CEfGa7sDx2VHEEnwrpiy8DX.body:
[Zirch](/zirch.bit) has the most up to date zite list because it is completely automated and updates every hour. [Kaffiene](/kaffiene.bit) and (I believe) [Snifferdog](/snifferdog.bit) are very out of date, and [RVRE](/rvre.bit) I think is less so, but still out of date. [EulerFinder](/13eFkhbXXQcJqd729zRLL9tMxxhz9d4UA6/) is similar to Zirch in that it is one of the most up to date ones and updates every hour, but it has slightly less zites than zirch.

Snifferdog was cloned from Kaffiene (but it might have some differences in what zites it has).

RVRE seems to look the best. Kaffiene, Snifferdog, and EulerFinder look decent/okay. Zirch looks pretty terrible.

RVRE, Kaffiene, and Snifferdog all use hand-written tags I believe, so the search function might be a bit better than Zirch, which doesn't have this, but instead just takes a portion of the index.html file and searches through that (as well as the zite's title *and description*). EulerFinder's searching is very similar to Zirch's.

I don't know very much about Zoogle Zearch since, like EulerFinder, it is pretty new. However, when I originally looked at it, it didn't seem like it had that many zites, but I'm very unsure about this so take this with a grain of salt.

Finally, [ZeroSites](/Sites.ZeroNetwork.bit) has a list of zites, but people have to manually add their zites to it. it also has no search feature. It seems to be pretty up to date for zites that people are adding, but perhaps there are still sites that haven't been added, I don't know. Also, in my opinion the categories could be expanded and the interface is a little annoying, but try it out and see for yourself whether you like it.

> [missesrobot](#comment_4_19WW28sn46rz9h15xf6NCELPdzxZ2YhbyB): Can people create their own hubs on ZeroMe, or just the site owners?

People can make their own hubs because you're essentially making your own zite when you do so (but allowing KopyKate to read the data of it). However, other people would need to download the hub to see the posts on it, of course. Imo, hubs in ZeroMe aren't that well done. But, that is not to say that a hub system for KopyKate wouldn't be good, because I think that it could if done right.

> [missesrobot](#comment_5_19WW28sn46rz9h15xf6NCELPdzxZ2YhbyB): So you just basically clone a hub..

Yes. However, you need to move your profile to the hub, too.

> [missesrobot](#comment_6_19WW28sn46rz9h15xf6NCELPdzxZ2YhbyB): Seems like I'd have to turn the current site into a hub (call in King Hub), and then create a central site.I'd have to experiment with clones for now though... Should KopyKate become a merger site? That's the question now. They say that it's the only way to allow embedding videos. It should also help with splitting large amounts of data, apparently.

KopyKate itself won't become a merger zite. But it will use merger zites to store the data for it.

The reason why merger zites will allow embedding videos into other zites is because zites can ask permission from the user to be able to read the files/information from the merger zite (in fact, this is also how the main zite works too. ZeroMe asks for permission to read from ZeroMe hubs. KopyKate would also have to do this). As far as I know, I don't know if this is possible without merger zites. Although, there is a [CORS plugin](https://zeronet.readthedocs.io/en/latest/site_development/zeroframe_api_reference/#corspermission-address) (clearnet), I'm not sure if you could use that instead of (or with) merger zites.

1512275153_12gAes6NzDS9E2q6Q1UXrpUdbPS6n.body:
## Concerning ZeroMedium Release Dates
I have decided to do a very small change with how versions are released for [ZeroMedium](/ZeroMedium.bit). The final release date for new versions will *not* change. What *will* change is when versions are released to [ZeroMedium BETA](/15HdD8ZwMLjzQhbDQcF8oRtkbxYxVS7JgU/). Upon the final release of a new version to the official zite, the next version after will also be released to ZeroMedium BETA. *This will give beta versions at least 2 weeks for bug fixes* before being released to the official zite. This also means that I will be working two versions ahead of the official zite.

So what does this mean now? It means that later today (it just turned 12:00am as I am writing this) I will release the next version (17.12b) to ZeroMedium BETA. However, because I did not have much time to get this version out, this version will not have very many changes.

1512623414_1HBy99H2dsCwevdYZp8VVC2SVG69D.body:
I think one of the main problems is that people aren't posting much stuff. A reason for why this is, which applies to me (but less so I think, since I do post original stuff sometimes) is that developers are too busy with their projects on here. I'm busy with ZeroMedium, ZeroNet Dev Center, ZeroDb, etc. so I can't post much stuff. Ivanq is busy with Git Center and I'm sure some other things. axeltherabbit is busy doing EulerFinder. KopyJane has her own projects (KopyKate/KopyKate Big, and ZeroCat ZeroNet Proxy, as well as other new projects she's working on). And Nofish is of course working on ZeroNet itself (and doing a pretty good job, ZeroNet gets a new revision multiple times a week to fix bugs, etc.). *Along with that, these people probably aren't developing for ZeroNet full-time, either.*

With that said, what might be making ZeroNet appear dead is *not the zite development, but the content of the zites.* Perhaps this could be because we don't have enough people who are *not* working on a zite that would actually have time to post more content.
One other thing that can be paired with this is the exposure ZeroNet is getting and the amount of people joining the network, which both *seem* to be pretty low.

> [james007](#comment_126_1DiRWRFXcVgQQ75cXnAG2pyxxjGo2VaH5): ZeroNet is still more heavily populated than I2P from my view. Certainly not dead.

I'm not saying there's no content, but there isn't very much. I'm definitely not saying ZeroNet is dead, I'm saying it may **appear** dead, and I give *possible* reasons for why it would *appear* this way.

> }

1512976214_18fU1ZPrTrUXVCYG4wDvk6fTB5ok4.body:
> [flappyearz](#comment_104_1QEfmMwKVxgR4rkREbdJYjgUmF3Zy8pwHt): And it's even worse, as I heard, since plenty of people with english as mother tongue haven't learnt grammar, they just try to get along mimicking what others do.

This is very wrong. Everyone learns grammar in school in the US and I'm pretty sure they do in Britain too.

>  I've learnt some grammar most of the US people can't even reproduce.

If you're talking about English grammar, I seriously doubt that. The only thing that other speakers learn that people who speak English as first language don't are the technical words for certain grammatical constructs (perfect, imperfect, infinitive, etc.), however, they still learn some (subject, object, etc). But people who speak English who have learned another language do learn these words as long as they apply to the language they are learning. Btw, it's a requirement for many (I would say majority, but I'm not totally sure about that) colleges to take 2 years of a foreign language.


Finally, it's very well known in Linguistics that speech evolves faster than writing. This is one of the main causes for why spelling doesn't evolve with changes in speech. Another reason is that when new words are brought into English, they are either not changed or barely changed. So, it isn't necessarily completely the fault of the English speakers for why the spelling is messed up. There was already one time where we tried to change the spelling for English to make it more consistent, it was somewhat successful (I believe one of the changes was using er instead of re?). I believe this was when English was standardized. What I'm mainly saying is that written language evolves slower than spoken language, and for this reason, there really isn't a way to completely get around the fact that spelling is going to either remain or become inconsistent with what is spoken. And trying to change it has it's own problems because not everyone will agree on the changes and a lot of people will forget them or just not obey them.

Also, something to note, the English spelling rules are more consistent than what people think.

1513321800_19WW28sn46rz9h15xf6NCELPdzxZ2.body:
> [missesrobot](#comment_44_19WW28sn46rz9h15xf6NCELPdzxZ2YhbyB): btw - does this work on any zeroframe, or only the zeroframes used in e.g. zeroup, zerome, etc?

Not completely sure what you mean exactly. Do you mean all zeroframe versions? As long as it can access the instance of your ZeroFrame class so it can call a few of the ZeroNet API commands, then it will work. It calls the wrapperPushState, so make sure you have the latest version (you can get that js file [here](https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroHello/blob/master/template-new/js/ZeroFrame.js), as posted by Nofish). You should look at the [GitHub](https://github.com/krixano/ZeroFrame-Router) I posted, because there is one thing you need to do to get it to work (make sure your zeroframe instance is called `page`, or do `page = zeroframeVariable` as a workaround):

> To navigate to a route, use the Router.navigate('/route') function. *You must also make sure your ZeroFrame instance is called page. (you can get around this by doing something as simple as page = zeroframe;).*
> 
> 
> The order in which you add routes matters. The URL which is added earlier and matches will be the one that is called.
> 
> 
> Note: You must call Router.listenForBack() in the OnRequest() function of your ZeroFrame class in order to detect when the user hits the back button and navigate to the correct route.

Also, this [GitHub page](https://github.com/krixano/ZeroFrame-Router) has much more information than the zite. The zite is a little outdated, but I think there weren't any breaking changes in newer versions released after the zite was last updated, so it still works with the latest version *I believe*.

1513428479_1EQuGEmS5J8SQ1xA6MM9KfubBb71u.body:
> [nekololi](#comment_89_1FzZsDQdh8wk71bDLxURPzmAt2FXehoNAB): i'm very confused by this topic. [...]

It says `Proxy` in the title. Proxy owners should be able to manage the zites that are on their server. Currently they can block all new zites, but that is not friendly to the users. Proxy owners can get into serious trouble from their hosting provider or government for having illegal content. If you want to view illegal content, use your own client instead of potentially getting someone else into trouble because of it.

> [conobs](#comment_10_1AjJqGb8AmPfgD62kEBBtqhg2hYDW5zner): Setting up a framework through which someone would need to submit their zite for review before being "approved" would enable the person with the power to approve or disapprove to block content they find objectionable. [...]

You are talking as if misssesrobot wan't this for *every* client. Not so. You probably missed the word `proxy` in the title. It's not really censorship, because they are not restricting your access to the zites - You can still download a client for yourself to do that.

And she's not asking that zite owners submit their zite for review. She's asking that anyone can submit a zite that they want added to the proxy if it hasn't already been added to the proxy. That way, she can look at it to see whether she can get in trouble or not from it, or whether she wants it on her server.

> [bornfree](#comment_6_1GNuATGPPFyvKngtWmbDrpo2D7u2rGM36m): Due to ZeroNet having a decentralized structure, and the ability to not take information down easily, I think it's somewhat normal for people to be cautious about uploading personal information here. Once the data is floating around in p2p, it has no right to be forgotten. We can encrypt content, at least until quantum computing comes and breaks all of are standard algorithms, but one should not assume that anything said here cannot be used against you in the global courts of law. Better to be a hermit than a prisoner of the state - Remember, even Winston Smith's best friends were members of the Ministry of Truth and the Thought Police... [...]

Taking information down from ZeroNet isn't much harder than from the clearnet. As long as you have your private keys, you can delete your information, sign your content, and everyone else will have that information deleted. The only exceptions are clients who are offline, but once they are back online, the information is then deleted, being quoted by other people, and clients that backup zites, but you can do that with clearnet sites too.

> [missesrobotone](#comment_9_1P7ZF1U5tMb3BKzp6jxWzz37VqGg2XiMhs): I've also had some questions regarding your SQL implementation, if you don't mind chipping in. You said it allows greater loading speeds on the proxy. Does the new script use Page.cmd in order to query databases? Would this new SQL implementation be able to query the big-file database in ZeroNet/data/content.db?

Yeah, I'm using the `dbQuery` command to query the db file. This allows it to do all of the logic on the server *and* limit that before sending the data to the person viewing the proxy. What I think really has the greatest affect on the speed is the fact that I'm able to limit the data (and do that *after* the sorting logic rather than before to get more accurate results) which reduces the amount of data being sent to the client. It had a much bigger impact than I expected, actually.

Here's where the code is for all of this: [https://github.com/krixano/ZeroMedium/blob/master/src/router_pages/home.js#L94](https://github.com/krixano/ZeroMedium/blob/master/src/router_pages/home.js#L94)

> [krixano](#comment_285_12gAes6NzDS9E2q6Q1UXrpUdbPS6nvuBPu): Yeah, I'm using the dbQuery command to query the db file. This allows it to do all of the logic on the server and limit that before sending the data to the person viewing the proxy. What I think really has the greatest affect on the speed is the fact that I'm able to limit the data (and do that after the sorting logic rather than before to get more accurate results) which reduces the amount of data being sent to the client. It had a much bigger impact than I expected, actually. [...]

Another thing I want to mention. Doing it like this also allows me to use OFFSET from SQL which will allow pagination. With the JS implementation, I had to query *all* of the stories and then sort them in javascript. This didn't allow me to do a limit, because then I would be sorting only a portion of the stories, which will lead to incorrect results overall. If I did it like that with pagination, then the sorting would only happen per page rather than overall. Doing the sorting in SQL before the limit will sort all of the stories and then limit the data.

I have an idea for a Social Network that I wan't to create that will work with some of what you described above. The only thing is for the particular implementation I have in mind, private circles might have to wait for private zites to be implemented, although there might be a way to do some encryption stuff and ability to allow only specific people to post via the rules in the users content.json file.

1519391319_17EoDsZVVgqN1WCV6uPjtiW8Wjmhw.body:
> [darkoceane](#comment_1_17EoDsZVVgqN1WCV6uPjtiW8WjmhwPuFMX): Thanks oracius and samp - so here is a specific concern I have - let's say I create a Zeronet site that is distributed across a number of peers. One of those peers decides to inject some malicious JS code into its directory which will upload each time another peer connects to that copy.  Is such an attack feasible? Is there anything in Zeronet designed to prevent this sort of attack?

The JS would have to run. I don't think any zite would knowingly run JS from one user on others' client (especially a JS file from a user's directory). Also, a user cannot modify anything about a zite except what is in their user directory.

It'd be a bit more feasible if either the attack was a file uploaded to a user directory that has a virus, or the zite owner has malicious code. For the first, that is dependent on the rules the zite owner created on which files are allowed in user directories. Any file types not listed/allowed are not transferred to other peers.

I'm not sure what you are meaning. All of those competing zites use their own code created entirely by their respective developer.

> [test20180221](#comment_22_13E6xCFLmbGYCNAPrKd3m5o6gTgnzMW4rd): I'm not a coder so that I don't understand the ZeroNet coding system,but IMHO there must be some kinds of base code which must be kept under careful management to keep the rule of networking and sharing and find peers etc. And I think that job must be done by @nofish.  [...]

That's the client. Zites talk to the client via an API called ZeroFrame. If I wanted to tell the client to  get/query something from a database, I would write something like: `zeroframe.cmd("dbquery", [sql_query_string]);` and it will give that back.

However, that's backend. All of the frontend stuff are created entirely by the zite's owner. This includes most of what a zite is, imo. The design of the website. Sorting, any features of that website. Even the database structure, how things are stored, etc.

For example: What I have written for ZeroMedium includes how the database is organized, functionality for adding a story, response, and upvote to the database, the searching mechanism (I had to write the SQL command for this), showing how many likes there are on a given story (again, SQL), the editor functionality (including markdown parsing), the design of the zite, etc.

*ZeroMedium is 5,500 lines of my own code (**not including any libraries I've used**)*

> [test20180221](#comment_23_13E6xCFLmbGYCNAPrKd3m5o6gTgnzMW4rd): Can I regard it that Zites over zeroframe are like kinds of variety of torrent clients based on a single core mechanism created or introduced by a man or a group in the beginning? And each client has its own features programmed by different programmers like you?  [...]

I'm not completely sure what you're meaning by the second half completely.

> Can I regard it that Zites over zeroframe are like kinds of variety of torrent clients based on a single core mechanism created or introduced by a man or a group in the beginning?
Not really. The client is just the program that handles how zites are shared/networked, the security of zites, etc. It then provides an API to these zites in the same way you have an API to regular websites that browsers provide. For example, there's javascript functions for opening sites in new window, for requesting information (via GET, POST, etc) from a server, etc. ZeroNet provides these same types of API procedures. 

Also, ZeroNet handles all of the security of the zites. Each zite is sandboxed (which is why all zites load in an iframe), and zites can't look at other zites, etc. I don't know much about this aspect of ZeroNet.

Few more things. ZeroNet also has ways for programmers to determine how their databases should look and how data is stored and seeded, etc. JSON files are used, and each user has their own folder under the zite's folder structure where their data is stored in a data.json file. This is so these files can be seeded without conflicts. Then, the ZeroNet client aggregates this into a sqlite database that is *not* seeded. When zite's ask ZeroNet for data from the database by giving it an SQL query, the client passes the query on to sqlite and gives back the result.

> [test20180221](#comment_26_13E6xCFLmbGYCNAPrKd3m5o6gTgnzMW4rd): So , if I need to fix a certain feature in ZeroMedium, I have to ask you not other guys else, right? [...]

Yes (kinda depends. If it's a problem with just ZeroMedium, then yes) and Yes. Except for one 150 line file that provides access to the ZeroFrame API via JavaScript - written by Nofish And of course any libraries used by the zite that weren't written by the zite owner.

Here's everything that the ZeroNet client handles:
* Networking - the peer-to-peer stuff, the seeding of zite files, optional files
* Security & Cryptography - permissions, sandboxing, merger zites and CORS (basically just allowing one zite to access the data of many other zites), addresses/keys, muting users
* Database - goes a bit with networking and security because files need to be separated out per user to mitigate conflicts, etc.
* News Feed - this is a special thing because it goes a bit beyond what the others do. This just allows zite's to put notification on the ZeroNet homepage/starting-page.
* API - ways to allow zites to do things that may be insecure for them to do directly or that interact with the above ZeroNet functionalities, querying from the database, writing to files, signing and publishing zites, requesting permissions, accessing data from other zites
  The api also provides access to procedures that are used to get around problems with the sandboxing (because of iframe problems). For example, opening a zite in a new tab, routing, etc.

Here's a link to the ZeroFrame API reference: [/17Kom2G5qNDc6NaQwv445h1gFzxkY3ZtZe/site_development/zeroframe_api_reference/](/17Kom2G5qNDc6NaQwv445h1gFzxkY3ZtZe/site_development/zeroframe_api_reference/)

> It looks like @nofish built a kind of Apache server and you built a kind of web sites on it. 

Exactly. Although, there are a few things that ZeroNet does that's a bit more than just a server - for example the News Feed plugin which allows zites to add things to the News Feed on ZeroNet's starting-page/homepage.

> I think with this scenario, others than @nofish also could build a kind of APIs needed by site builders, could they?
> Of course the security matters and so fourth should be confirmed by responsible persons like @nofish, right?

Yes. There are plugins that you can make for ZeroNet that can provide more features built in to the client where zite's can then access them from the ZeroFrame API. In fact, the merger site feature (which allows zites to access information from other zites) and many other ZeroNet features are written as plugins. Anyone could write a plugin and anyone could easily "install" it by just dragging the folder with the python code of the plugin into a certain folder.

> [test20180221](#comment_34_13E6xCFLmbGYCNAPrKd3m5o6gTgnzMW4rd): What would happen if I change the ZeroTalk zite code in my server directory??

It would work, but you wouldn't be able to publish that to anyone else because site's are protected by a signature which uses the zite owners private key. Also, whenever the zite get's updated, it will revert back.

But you can submit a pull request on GitHub.

> [test20180221](#comment_35_13E6xCFLmbGYCNAPrKd3m5o6gTgnzMW4rd): zites updating doesn't affect the change I made in my local folder?

If you are meaning your changes to the zite's code, then yes. If you are meaning the information in your user folder (where your own posts are stored), those are signed with a signature using your user id's private key and published/seeded to everyone else.

My [Users and Databases tutorial](/14pM9huTYzJdyQyHRj6v2kfhMe8DrxwpGt/?/tutorials/users_databases_in_zeronet) on ZeroNet Dev Center explains how users and databases work, including how user files are verified, how they are stored, how they are used for the databases, how Id Providers (Certificate Authorities) work, etc.

> [test20180221](#comment_37_13E6xCFLmbGYCNAPrKd3m5o6gTgnzMW4rd): Did you write those tutorials?

I wrote 4 out of 5 of them. @glightstar also helped with the first tutorial. @lola wrote the tutorial that shows how to make ZeroNet plugins in python.

> Where is the user folder in which my posts are collected?
Your user folder is under each zite's directory in: 'ZeroNet/data/[zite address directory]/data/users/[your public key -address]/'.

> [test20180221](#comment_36_13E6xCFLmbGYCNAPrKd3m5o6gTgnzMW4rd): So, my changing zite's code gets reverted whenever I update the zite? [...]

> So, my changing zite's code gets reverted whenever I update the zite?
I believe so because when the zite is updated, you redownload the updated files from other peers (but only after first checking that the signature is correct - that the changes are in fact from the zite owner).
I plan on making many more tutorials, but I've been busy with many other things.

1519632694_13E6xCFLmbGYCNAPrKd3m5o6gTgnz.body: It's the `users.json` file under ZeroNet's data folder. It has all of your private keys, including the one for your id's.

You can read [my tutorial on ZeroNet Dev Center](/DevCenter.bit/?/tutorials/users_databases_in_zeronet), which covers the very basics of how databases work within ZeroNet. If you are a complete beginner, I also recommend reading my other tutorials before this one (starting with "The Basics" first, and you can skip "Tips and Tricks" and "Write a Plugin"). The tutorial also describes users because they are very much related to databases.

After you've finished my tutorial(s), there are more tutorials created by @gitcenter (aka @ivanq / imachug) [here on GitHub](https://github.com/krixano/ZeroNet-Dev-Center/issues/28) ([direct download link](https://github.com/krixano/ZeroNet-Dev-Center/files/1334487/The.truth.about.ZeroNet.zip)) that go over more details, including how to actually create the databases, use them, update them, etc.

1520192492_16NS3rBdW9zpLmLSQoD8nLTtNVsRF.body:
> so a wall of text should not imply I'm upset. I just type a lot.

Hmm... interesting.

I going to have to disagree with *some* of this. I think training yourself to feel *no* emotion whatsoever is very bad. There's a reason why they call people who can't feel emotion psychopaths. Emotion serves a purpose believe it or not. Now, that's not to say overreaction is a good thing, however, I think people take things for overreaction when it isn't.

I think that the internet needs more people who actually care about another's emotions and their own. They may have the integrity to stand up to people who are bullies - who make the internet not a good place. But it's also important that these people not judge a phrase (or long paragraph) until they've had enough information to determine exactly how something typed was meant - and even still, I personally believe it's better to give the benefit of the doubt. And by getting enough information, I mean at least having the respect to read what the other person said entirely - You can't expect to be in good wits if you don't have all the information. Of course there's always exceptions, so if that person happens to intentionally make statements that bother you, it might be better to leave them alone, but I think you better be careful on your judgement of them and be absolutely sure.

People don't get mad at nothing. They get mad at their own interpretations of something. Which is why emotion isn't always the problem, it's the interpretation. This applies to politics as well - everyone should know about the techniques used to manipulate your emotions in propaganda. Having no emotions doesn't really help you, but having the knowledge to correct your interpretations, to be wary of your own judgements, and know when someone is manipulating you does.

> [frosticnotion](#comment_41_1J6csQA9K9NZaYUiCG5C2XQRF85yB5PGaJ): The tutorial example of blog_single has an issue in which a post that is in the process of being added (the page in which you input title and description) is only cancelled if you click the button cancel. By pressing publish or the browsers back button, both ways the post is added. I'm hoping to figure out a way to make it so that using the browsers back button would result in cancelling the new post because publish was not clicked.

Are you adding to the user's json file (or signing) before the publish button is clicked? Because if you are, then the post is being added to the file, but not pushed out to other people, before the user clicks the publish button and probably before the back button is hit, and will therefor show up for the user (and show up to everyone else the next time the publish button is clicked). Instead, I would write to the data file, sign, and publish after the publish button is clicked.

1520435778_18YsrRv5LsoqhKgirUbKNy8tXCRN1.body:
> [leftside](#comment_47_16dEowtNbV89NxPcDrAKkmnuXtiJVoVcDm): Thanks for the more details. Actually I still don't have a full understanding on the concept of the optional files. :p

Optional files are just files that are not downloaded when you download the zite, but rather when you need that file. For example, on KopyKate, there are a lot of videos, so it would take forever to download all of those videos when you *first* visit the zite - and you may not even want all of those videos. So instead, they are marked as optional and are only downloaded when you actually want to watch the video. Then, people who have downloaded that file (which isn't necessarily the same as the amount of people who have downloaded the zite) seed to other people who may also be downloading the video.

> [leftside](#comment_52_16dEowtNbV89NxPcDrAKkmnuXtiJVoVcDm): Thank u, krixano :)One more question. How can I set a file as an optional file?

The zite owner adds that functionality into the zite. For example, when you upload a video to KopyKate, it's automatically set by the zite as optional.

> [rcastanonz](#comment_13_1PGFKCfMSL1QdudndfYCo4mGM8E8XKzMMG): @krixano I would like to know more exactly, what does merge mean in this context. I tried to translate it to something like Fusionable. I was wondering if it meant to be something like "Mixed zites". [...]

Well, a merger zite in ZeroNet is a zite whose database is merged into another zite. For example, ZeroMe Hubs are merger zites. They are separate zites whose databases are merged together to form the ZeroMe database, which is the information ZeroMe shows when visiting it. By adding a hub merger zite, it get's merged in with the ZeroMe database and it's content is shown on ZeroMe. - I'm not sure how that would translate into other languages, but hopefully this helps.

"File Sharing" would be a participle or *maybe* a verb - depending on how you look at it. In my initial view, I thought it more of a participle with how I'm using it. A participle is a verb used as an adjective, and in this case, the adjective is also a substantive (meaning the noun the adjective modifies is implied - "File Sharing *Zites*" - Zites is implied and not explicit - essentially, the adjective/participle is used kinda as a noun). However, I suppose it *could* maybe be a verb if the implied statement was "[Zites that are] File Sharing".
