1521009385_1Cz286mxKa8Ujy6nj222YKegBkz1A.body:
Old addons wouldn't be supported anyways because they switch to multi-process which none of the old addons support, afaik. Also, if the *only* reason for you saying that Firefox is bad is because of the addons, then that's a weak argument, because the whole addons situation was intentional, not a bug. The new Firefox functions exactly as it's supposed to and is therefore not bad *based on what it's supposed to do*, and in my experience, is *much much* faster than the older versions. It's like saying Mac is bad because it can't run Windows programs.

The only thing about the new Firefox that isn't necessarily the best would be what you can actually do with the extensions/addons. However, this is due to tradeoffs. You trade addon flexibility for security, multi-process, etc. Furthermore, basing whether something is good or not on *one* thing such as addons is also a weak argument imo (not saying you are doing this, just giving my perspective on opinions regarding Firefox). You can't get away with basing conclusions on *one* thing in Science, so why should you with this.

1526435674_19XCfah7iuo9zYqk7GoTDXVNp4p5B.body: ZeroNet uses client-side web technologies. Therefore, you can use anything that will work for regular browsers. Which means that the *end result* must be javascript, css, and html. However, there are many many languages for the web that compile to JavaScript, which is how web developers get around the fact that browsers only support JavaScript. This also goes for languages for styling that compile to CSS. Examples of these are: Typescript, Dart, SASS, LESS, etc.

1526455814_12gAes6NzDS9E2q6Q1UXrpUdbPS6n.body:
> [quantumkitty](#comment_25_1NZftAz9VSawGF5JgMYGFv4ByoKEaQbNZu): It's hard to create original content. As soon as you come up with an idea you think is good - bang - somebody else has done it! [...]

That's definitely true. I wanted to write this here to hopefully gauge what *might* be stopping people from posting original content, what ZeroNet may need, etc.

I'm going to be trying to create original content on here.  Since I have more time, I'll be making videos and more written stuff.

Ideas so far:
* Make easy to create content
* Make easy to share content
* Get people to view/use content
  - Have enough people on the platform
* Make people want to create content
  - Have people donate
  - Have some type of attribution system

I think the first step that I'll be working toward is Making it easy to create content on ZeroMedium by vastly improving the experience on there. @ivanq / @gitcenter is working on  a CMS for ZeroNet called ZMS, which I think will improve this quite a bit as well.

For making it easy to share content, I started up this project a while ago called *ZeroGraph*. It was my attempt at making an alternative to OpenGraph for ZeroNet. I may start that back up to help with sharing content. I will also be continuing to improve Important Zites, which should help discoverability of content hopefully.

To help get people on the platform so people view/use the content, I think the Docs need to be vastly improved, not only for ZeroNet, but for zites also, to get more people involved in creating issues and pull requests for zites. This also means the devs need to respond well to this.
There needs to be more and better startup guides, and perhaps an updated tour of ZeroNet video that shows many of the well-done zites on here (I'm planning on a video like this). I think the homepage when someone first starts up ZeroNet with a fresh install could be improved a bit.

For the last one, I don't have many ideas.

> [quantumkitty](#comment_26_1NZftAz9VSawGF5JgMYGFv4ByoKEaQbNZu): I've got ideas,  I just struggle with motivation I guess. I suppose the only way to stay motivated is to remind yourself of the reason why you do things in the first place. Personally, I think ZeroNet has too much potential for me to abandon it.

Yeah, I struggle with motivation sometimes. But just thinking about this and some of the zite ideas I have are getting me excited to start working on stuff!

Deep Learning is way over my head, but I'd like to learn a little bit of it someday.

I was thinking about making a video zite a while ago, I just never made it because I didn't want to make something that somebody else was already putting a lot of work into making.

I think a few things in the ZeroNet core also need to be improved to help with some of these points. These are some *ideas*:
* Performance
  - Starting up ZeroNet after being off of it for months is very painful! Not only does it take a long time to download stuff (which may not be able to be improved, not sure on that), but you can't visit any zite that accesses a database because the loading of all the other databases blocks it.
  - ZeroNet needs multi-threading and parallelization
  - ZeroNet needs to prioritize the downloading of files of the zite you are *currently looking at*, not sure how possible this is.
  - Ability for dev to set the files that should be prioritized to download as early as possible before other files. I would like the index html file and the main js file to be downloaded before images, etc. - not sure how possible or realistic this is.
* Backing up the files you're seeding and your zites easily.
  - The Download Zite as Zip File feature helps quite a bit with this, but it still needs to be improved
  - A zite where you can select all of the zites you want to download zips of that way you don't have to manually go to each and every zite
  - Move user's files (aside from data files) to one location so that you can actually use them outside of ZeroNet, reduce duplications, etc.
* ID's
  - It might be good to provide a way to backup or somehow sync your users.json file between multiple clients. However, not sure how this would be done *securely*
  - Allow multiple id's from same provider so that all of them are listed when selecting a user.
* Documentation, Tutorials, Tour
* Better Android client

I think many of these help get more people on here by making ZeroNet more usable and easier.

@nofish

> [quantumkitty](#comment_29_1NZftAz9VSawGF5JgMYGFv4ByoKEaQbNZu): Indeed, those things have been mentioned before. We made the mistake of playing competitively. We had a dozen different zites doing the exact same thing. We should try to play more cooperatively this time. Like I said, KopyKate is just a clone of ZeroUp.. so I'd be happy to give the private key away.. then just focus on what matters the most.

I completely agree. We need to work together more. Nobody really seems to help each other out with their zites much. Sure, we give ideas and tell how to do certain things, but there's no pull requests, etc. We need to make much better Documentation, for ZeroNet and for Zites, etc.

Furthermore, I think zites should play better with eachother functionally also. That's one of the things I was trying to help with ZeroGraph. This is also why I plan to make it easy to integrate KopyKate videos and ZeroLSTN music into ZeroMedium articles. This goes along with my "Make easy to share content" point.

ZeroMe should be able to show a video from KopyKate, or an image from a blog, etc.

> [quantumkitty](#comment_30_1NZftAz9VSawGF5JgMYGFv4ByoKEaQbNZu): But now that we have soooo many video zites, we should probably focus on something other than videos.

ZeroGraph is going to be able to store information on all types of content, including zites, articles, pages, videos, images, etc. I imagine it being very similar to OpenGraph functionally. This will improve the sharing stuff because zites will be able to show this preview from ZeroGraph without having to download the zite it comes from. Then, when they click on the link, they will download the zite it comes from if not already downloaded and go to it.

This should not only help with my idea on making zites play better with each other, but also help sharing content **while still maintaining that separation between the zites - basically no need to duplicate stuff by reuploading to multiple zites.**

It's really just a zite that has a simple database that stores only the necessary info for previews and zites can post to it and get stuff from it using the CORS permission and the "as" ZeroFrame command (which is how I do the searchig for Important Zites).

## Installer Update 1.2
* Added Data directory shortcut to start menu

> [a7oiz](#comment_2_1PMuHrGm4GFBBNbvRgr8zvyyRTc3rHpGYz): How can I install the P2P plugin in macOS？

1. Shutdown ZeroNet, Download [this zip](https://github.com/imachug/ZeroNet/archive/p2p-msg.zip)
2. Open it, go into "ZeroNet-p2p-msg", go into "plugins"
3. Open, in new window the plugins directory under the ZeroNet root (it *may* be under `ZeroNetRoot/core/plugins` if using bundle)
4. Drag the "P2P-messages" folder from the zip file to the newly opened plugins directory in the other window.
5. Start ZeroNet back up

1527003512_13mmQytg34syftQYB5eFFMA9ATsGG.body:
> [vychlop](#comment_3_13mmQytg34syftQYB5eFFMA9ATsGGmjk46): Personally, I believe that the ability to clone and fork sites is important to keeping them alive and making it hard to censor.

We *can* clone and fork zites. It's just not automatic. You have to do it manually. And some zite owners allow the clone button, which you can find by clicking the 3 dots next to the zite name in ZeroHello. This will essentially create a new zite owned by you, with the same files as the zite you are cloning. If this button isn't allowed by the zite owner, then you can just copy the files of the zite. Almost every zite on here, that I know of, is Open Source and most likely in GitHub.

> > thunder33345: tho maybe something about githistory, where peers will keep something like a gitlog of each changes, to prevent repeat saving unnecessary data, and easy reverts shall anything happen, but this relies on peers to be bothered to save the history
> 
> I honestly thought that would happen automatically. People who just visit store up to the site storage limit, and people who mirror store the whole thing. I didn't think you can affect the mirrored copies.

Optional files and the zite limit are different from git history, because there's no history for the actual files. In both these cases, you are just downloading some of the *files* rather than all of them, but the files you do download are going to *always be the latest version* because there is no patches or git history, etc.

However, I do agree that either cloning/downloading of versions of zites should be easier (and perhaps optionally automatic) or there should be some type of dvcs history or patches. I will actually be making a tool to make it much easier to backup zites, that will be shipped with my new [ZeroNet Exe Installer](/Talk.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Topic:1526846299_12gAes6NzDS9E2q6Q1UXrpUdbPS6nvuBPu/ZeroNet+Exe+Installer+Beta+P2P+Message+Plugin+by+GitCenter).

I never said it stored user data. I said it allows you to clone/fork the zite in the sense of version control forking. Forking is *not* cloning everything including data, that'd be something else. Forking is taking the source code and using it on your own zite/server with your own data. > [xinyi](#comment_7_15kHQPHwsB18wZyPVftd49ZBdncgdTmA4f): Even their server code is proprietary. They never had the spirit of FLOSS. Its funny how many websites host their server code on GitHub when even GitHub keep its backend code private. Gmail centralized the decentralized email network and GitHub centralized the decentralized version control system. [...]

The solution to the centralization on ZeroNet thing is merger zites. Git Center uses them very well for this type of thing. So do a few others, but some don't I don't think (e.g. ZeroMe).

However, I'm going to disagree that everything should be decentralized. I think some things need to be centralized, and I think the way things are centralized on ZeroNet (centralization through decentralization) is *a lot* better than the clearnet.

> [xinyi](#comment_9_15kHQPHwsB18wZyPVftd49ZBdncgdTmA4f): You are spot on! Merger zites is the way to go. [...]

The best example I can give right now: The way GitCenter has one merger zite as a list of repository names associated with their merger zite addresses. It is centralized because one zite has all of the links. The benefit this provides is that you only have to download one zite to explore all of the repositories. This could, however, be split up into multiple zites based on category (etc.), which would kind of reduce centralization, but not eliminate it.

Of course, if there was a way to have zites where the owner can only modify the zite code, but not user files, then that would basically get rid of the need for merger zites for the case that we are talking about - because then everyone would own their own data, and that data wouldn't be able to be removed by the zite owner. This would also prevent having to find and download many merger zites just to see the data. Furthermore, for people, including the zite owner, that don't want to seed certain content, they can mute a specific person.

1535451536_1EoqbSwvxRuRKj7vpeK79wuGXdpq2.body:
> [d14na2](#comment_20_1EoqbSwvxRuRKj7vpeK79wuGXdpq2wbqfM): QUESTIONS: What is the best practice in the Zeronet for notifications (its something we absolutely NEED in 0Explorer)? Although I'm using the @mentions here, how does everyone actually receive the notifications when mentioned? Thanks!

A website needs to setup the NewsFeed plugin to work with their site by giving ZeroNet (or rather, the plugin) an sql query to match everything that should show up in the notifications. These notifications can technically be shown on any zite (as long as it has the admin permissions), but the main zite that everyone sees them on is the ZeroHello zite (because this acts like a homepage for ZeroNet). These sql queries are run against each corresponding zite's database every time you go to the ZeroHello page.

So, when you follow something on a zite, the zite gives an sql query to this NewsFeed plugin, which then stores it for use later on (for example, on ZeroHello). This sql query would get all of the related information for the thing you are following on the zite.

I believe: When ZeroHello gets the notifications, it doesn't get every query and run it against each corresponding zite. Instead, it just runs a ZeroNet API function/command that does all of this behind the scenes and returns the list of notifications, to then be displayed by ZeroHello.

The order in which these notifications show up depends on the date value given in the sql query.

1536308470_1EAD2zXkzgJf6M7xQ4jG5FHCxUTez.body:
Zites *do* change the JSON data, which then updates the sqlite database. They *never* use an update sql query to change the database. Instead the json data is changed, signed, and published, and the local client as well as other clients look at the json data and update the local db based on that.

So the actual process, afaik, is like this:

1. Take /data/users/<public-key>/data.json
2. Inject it into a SQLite database
3. Update /data/users/<public-key>/data.json
5. Sign and Publish/Share
4. Extract the modified information from data.json into SQLite

1536996506_1J2sR4SBGqowvrAGW2gmfyd1BsjQL.body:
> [mappedmind](#comment_6_1J2sR4SBGqowvrAGW2gmfyd1BsjQLh1kme): Kaffine, seems to be working now. When I first tried it nothing happened when I typed "math" into the search bar. Now, when I type math three items come up automatically. Pressing "enter" doesn't seem to do anything.

There are 3 types of "Search Engines" in ZeroNet:

1. User-submitted Zites - Examples being 0list, ZeroSites, and [Important Zites](/1MiS3ud9JogSQpd1QVmM6ETHRmk5RgJn6E) (although, only Important Zites has a search function). Zite creators submit their zites to an index.
2. Local Search Engine - Example includes Important Zites (which can search other zites that you have local to your computer) as well as [KxoNetwork](/1GTVetvjTEriCMzKzWSP9FahYoMPy6BG1P) and ZeroUp Search. These can search through zites *locally* (meaning zites you already have downloaded). These zites are able to achieve this using the ZeroNet CORS functionality - which means all of these will require you to accept the CORS permission for each zite it searches (or, in the case of Horizon and Kaffiene, enable and accept the zites you want to have locally searched).
3. Centralized Search Engine - Examples include Horizon, Kaffiene, Zirch, EulerFinder, and other older ones. These have a backend client (usually ran by the zite owner) that run looking for links/zites in various ways from zites that it gathers. These various ways can include crawling everything visible on a page (for example using Selenium), or looking for links in user data files. Some of these, like Kaffie and Horizon, can also do Local Searching.

> [caryoscelus](#comment_79_13oRBYqNeUr6Tvgt4KkAT9FT4XRiKFBjnE): You forgot to mention ZeroHello. Not sure how it works under the hood (perhaps the same CORS?..), but it's the most available search platform on 0net because it's a "default" site.

ZeroHello doesn't use CORS in the sense of the cors permissions. It uses two things. 1. It can search through anything that is in the News Feed 2. It can search using queries provided by the "newsfeed" entry in a zite's dbschema file. It can access both of these because it is an admin zite (it has the admin permission by default).

Anyways, I didn't mention it because it's the most obvious, not many zites are supporting all data with it, and because I don't think it's that good. And I think promoting the defaults over everything else reduces the ability for new zites to become known and popular, especially since the "default" demo zites (ZeroTalk, ZeroHello, etc.) prefer the defaults over others (I don't see ZeroHello, on first run of ZeroNet, showing other zites besides these, even though some of them have become very popular and are even better than the defaults).

They have a beta version of the plugin for Firefox that doesn't use a proxy, called [overbitenx](https://addons.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/addon/overbitenx/) (which has to communicate with another program you must install, called Onyx, which you can all find on the [github page](https://github.com/classilla/overbitenx)). With Linux you'll be fine, but for Windows, you will have to use the [Cygwin](https://cygwin.com/) version because the other one (lynx Windows installers, etc.) doesn't come with https support, but the cygwin version does (btw, when I installed Cygwin, I had to manually check that I wanted lynx installed).

I *completely* forgot - there's also the Windows Subsystem for Linux that you can use to download lynx, w3m, links, links2, elinks, etc. (these are all text-based browsers for Linux, some of them, like lynx, support gopher).

[VF-1](https://github.com/solderpunk/VF-1) is also a really good Gopher client written in python.

1538004633_1Ny31DdkRx1wcA8bv2Uiybbex8YCX.body:
Imo, these are problems with the law rather than problems with ZeroNet. And they vary based on country.

But, yes, when you download a zite, you seed it to others, and you'll continue to seed it until you delete it from your client.

> [djinn](#comment_3_1Ny31DdkRx1wcA8bv2Uiybbex8YCXcYQTN): How do you delete sites from your client? I may be inclined toward regular purges.

In ZeroHello, you can click the 3 dots next to the zite and click delete. You can also drag the 0 button on the top right to the left, scroll down, and there's a delete button there.

> [djinn](#comment_6_1Ny31DdkRx1wcA8bv2Uiybbex8YCXcYQTN): See this is what I am concerned about though. I navigate to a site unknowing that there is bad content there.... Do I suddenly have all that bad content on my computer?

Yes. You download a zite when you visit it. You also seed the zite. **unless** the illegal content uses optional files, then you must manually "seed"/download that file (depending on how the zite implements it). For example: Videos on KopyKate Big are not automatically downloaded. You have to manually do it through the zite.

There are a few different ways to help with preventing you from visiting/downloading/seeding illegal content, some of them implemented some of them not.
* Important Zites, Horizon, ZeroSites, and other indexes or search engines could have tags to tell you whether they have illegal content - this one isn't implemented very well, but Important Zites does at least notify of NSFW.
* Blocklists - There are blocklist zites that a person can create (e.g. NopeList) which basically is a list managed by one person, and if you enable that blocklist, anything on the list will be blocked. I haven't quite used this feature and it was released when I was off ZeroNet at the time, so I don't know too much more about this.
* You can block zites individually yourself rather than going through a blocklist.
* You can also block users so that only a specific user's data will not be downloaded or seeded. These can also be provided by blocklists.
* Some people who create zites will ban/remove illegal content from their zites.

There aren't very many options to help with this, as many of the things go completely against the structure of ZeroNet. You can't really not accidentally host illegal content at some point and have ZeroNet work p2p at the same time (unless you want to introduce some temporary storage system, but that makes no sense imo, and you'd still be downloading it temporarily - in this respect it's not much different from the clearnet).

> [djinn](#comment_8_1Ny31DdkRx1wcA8bv2Uiybbex8YCXcYQTN): Thank you for the detailed explanation. This is extremely helpful and I really appreciate it. In regards to stopping users from hosting illegal content I actually have an idea about that. Maybe you could give some input on my idea. [...]

Tbh, I don't understand the concerns (regarding downloading illegal content) because when you visit illegal websites on the clearnet, those are also downloaded (just temporarily).

Also, optional files helps with the seeding part, but zite owners *do* have to make things optional. So, perhaps a way to make non-optional files optional per the user could be helpful. 1552634420_1e2mHauMGG8GgSDvaaPrNanxvaxwp.body:
> [pubg](#comment_24_1PqrpogAwPjPf9T7bJjWWAjzTaRQcXLYCR): yes, it would encrpt the traffic if you use zeronet in your local machine because the file server would do that but ui server (http) would not.

**This** is the important distinction. The *file server* - which handles distributing files over the network as well as trackers, etc. - **is** encrypted.

The *UI server* - which is an HTTP Web Server ran *locally* to deliver the web pages from your *local* computer to your *local* webbrowser does **not** - and it's not needed. With exception to ZeroNet Proxies, where this HTTP Web Server is *not local*, in which case, whether it has TLS encryption or not depends on whether the Proxy has enabled this. 0net.io, for example, *does* because you can see the "https" prefixing the address when you navigate to that proxy.

Btw, on ZeroNet's GitHub Page (https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet), you can see `TLS encrypted connections` listed under "Features".

1552623438_1EZTWytasXcKdiUFnN4KHqAfvg1nw.body: Are you asking whether one device can connect directly to another via wifi rather than going through a router? This is what Chromecasts are able to do (however, I don't know if Chromecasts act like a router, or if they use Wifi Direct). There's also **Wifi Direct**.

> [kai0](#comment_1002_1EZTWytasXcKdiUFnN4KHqAfvg1nwkTkKv): two ISP cable two wifi, clients under this two wifi can't find each other locally. have to connect to ISP sever to find each other. and ISP sever can block your client.

This is precisely what projects like Cjdns and mesh networks are trying to fix.

Btw, if you have two devices on two different networks under two different ISPs, then **they aren't local to each other**, so they can never find each other - unless you go out into the internet or you somehow bridge the connection between the two routers. Also, mesh networking.

> [kai0](#comment_1003_1EZTWytasXcKdiUFnN4KHqAfvg1nwkTkKv): if a computer can connect to two wifi at same time then two clients under two different wifi can find each other locally

So you are saying both devices are connected to each other's networks as well as their own?

> [kai0](#comment_1004_1EZTWytasXcKdiUFnN4KHqAfvg1nwkTkKv): zeronet still work fine because we have local find and sever can't block local find

I have no idea what you're saying or trying to do.

If a device is not connected to the same router as another, then they can never find each other locally, which means they must go through the internet or there must be some bridge to bridge traffic between the two routers/networks.

If a device is connected to the same router as another, then they are local to each other, in which case each device has a private (internal) ip address which allows one computer to send data to the other via the router.

In the case of mesh networking, however, there is no central router to handle routing of traffic from one device to another using the ip address. Therefore, mesh networking must rely on other means to route traffic to the correct device in the network. Cjdns allows for each device of a mesh network to use each other (each device within the network acts like a router) to route traffic to the correct ip address within the network.

Basically, if they are local in a network with a router - you can use the private (internal) ip address of the device to send data to it.
If they are local in a mesh network, then you must use a different means. Cjdns provides this means. Don't ask me how this is done - I don't know anything about Cjdns.
If they are not local, they must go through the internet - in which case you would use the *public* ip address of the network. There's also port forwarding you would have to deal with in certain cases.

ZeroNet is able to discover all of the local devices in a network with **Local Peer Discovery**. I believe it just broadcasts a message to every device in the network and all the devices with ZeroNet running will respond (I don't know much about this, so take this with a grain of salt).

> [kai0](#comment_1005_1EZTWytasXcKdiUFnN4KHqAfvg1nwkTkKv): computer can work as a wifi, if we can think of wifi as a mobile device then two wifi can connect to one computer, so two wifi can exchange data.

A computer cannot **be** "a wifi". Wifi is a **protocol** and technology to allow communication between two devices. Devices **use** wifi to communicate.

Yes, a computer can connect to two different access points from two different networks. In which case, the device will be on **both** networks. Therefore, what I have written previously still applies.

>If a device is connected to the same router as another, then they are local to each other, in which case each device has a private (internal) ip address which allows one computer to send data to the other via the router.
>
>In the case of mesh networking, however, there is no central router to handle routing of traffic from one device to another using the ip address. Therefore, mesh networking must rely on other means to route traffic to the correct device in the network. Cjdns allows for each device of a mesh network to use each other (each device within the network acts like a router) to route traffic to the correct ip address within the network.
>
>Basically, if they are local in a network with a router - you can use the private (internal) ip address of the device to send data to it.
>If they are local in a mesh network, then you must use a different means. Cjdns provides this means. Don't ask me how this is done - I don't know anything about Cjdns.
>If they are not local, they must go through the internet - in which case you would use the public ip address of the network. There's also port forwarding you would have to deal with in certain cases.
>
>ZeroNet is able to discover all of the local devices in a network with Local Peer Discovery. I believe it just broadcasts a message to every device in the network and all the devices with ZeroNet running will respond (I don't know much about this, so take this with a grain of salt).

Just as a sitenote:
* Kxo**Vid** is the Video Zite. Kxo**Id** is just an id provider. Kxo**Vid** allows you to sign-in *with* Kxo**Id**. You *Register* Kxo**Id** on Kxo**Network**, not on Kxo**Vid**.
* Also, categories are hubs are merged zites. They are all the same thing. A hub is another name for a merged zite - ZeroMe also uses this lingo. Hubs in ZeroMe **are** merged zites. However, I like to called "merged zites" merg**er** zites (it makes more sense to me considering I'm a Native English speaker). Finally, KxoVid uses hubs/merged-zites based on Categories, therefore I also just call them categories.
  - So by Ecology Merger Zite, I mean Ecology Category, Ecology Hub, Ecology Merged-Zite, etc. - they are all the same thing.

If it is down, Then it's not *completely* true that ZeroNet is unusable. There are other Id providers, including KaffieId and [KxoId](/1GTVetvjTEriCMzKzWSP9FahYoMPy6BG1P/?/create-id) - both of which use ZeroNet's network. 1553364134_131Seivv6aH8vnohPmYPcPwPfZ1a5.body: Idk, all I can say is make sure you have commas in the correct places. Did you accidentally delete the comma after that max_size value?

> [klu9](#comment_110_131Seivv6aH8vnohPmYPcPwPfZ1a5ubMMs): @styromaniac: Do you mean you get an error when you try visiting my blog?

Ok, here's where the syntax error is, in the "permissions" section:

```json
"nofish@zeroid.bit": {"max_size": 20000}
   "klu9@zeroid.bit": {"max_size": 200000}
```

You need a comma after `"nofish@zeroid.bit": {"max_size": 20000}`.

So it should look like this:
```json
"nofish@zeroid.bit": {"max_size": 20000},
   "klu9@zeroid.bit": {"max_size": 200000}
```

> [klu9](#comment_112_131Seivv6aH8vnohPmYPcPwPfZ1a5ubMMs): On a related note, anyone know why is more space given to a user "if registered using bitmessage"? And how do we do that? (I thought registering with ZeroID included a bitmessage ID; at least it also gave me something starting BM-2cU... when I got my ZeroID)

Because bitmessage is harder to do for spammers, which means they are more trustworthy.

> [klu9](#comment_113_131Seivv6aH8vnohPmYPcPwPfZ1a5ubMMs): I see.Do I, as a ZeroID user, have a bitmessage ID too (that BM-2cu etc), and can I use it to sign in on other people's sites? (It doesn't seem to be listed as a sign-in option.)

No. You must go through a different registration process, which is what makes it harder for spammers to do. You do it through BitMessage (a secure messaging program - I don't know much else about this). I'm unsure if this registration process is still up and running or not.

> [klu9](#comment_114_131Seivv6aH8vnohPmYPcPwPfZ1a5ubMMs): Thanks. [...]

Sorry it's taken me so long.

Change this section:
```json
"cert_signers": {
   "zeroid.bit": ["1iD5ZQJMNXu43w1qLB8sfdHVKppVMduGz"]
  },
```
to:
```json
"cert_signers": {
   "zeroid.bit": ["1iD5ZQJMNXu43w1qLB8sfdHVKppVMduGz"],
    "kxoid.bit": ["12F5SvxoPR128aiudte78h8pY7mobroG6V"]
  },
```

The first part is the namecoin address, which is what is put at the end of user id's after the "@" symbol (e.g. krixano@**kxoid.bit**). The second is the public address/key from which certificates can be verified against to ensure a user id was actually created by that id provider. Usually Id providers will give you this. For example, the website where you register KxoId does give you this (at the bottom of the create id page).

This allows people with a kxoid.bit id to add information into their own user's folder on the zite and tells other peers of the zite to accept these additions. Then, you need to allow them to sign in, which requires changing some code. I'll look at what needs to be changed right now.

I think there's one more thing you need to do... You need to change the source code. I'll look up what you need to change right now.

> [quantumworld](#comment_314_1AdWXZdPUimpXoGNXUBde2CHR7gLf4onxE): A plug in for Linux should be an executable shell script that auto installs the code to the right folder on zeronet without breaking any other programs. Later version should include an icon of some kind that links to the executable shell script. This should all be done at the user level and absolutely no accelerated privileges should be given to that plugin.  A gui version in zeronet with a pull down menu that would ask you to load that (executable script) program would be the easiest for new users. (Now where this would go in zeronet is the question.)

I already have ideas on exactly how I image this being done. Basically, a zite can request ZeroNet to install a plugin from a zip file - this way we can have zites like KxoNetwork have an "install" button. Then ZeroNet will give a notification in the top right asking if you want to install the plugin. Then, if the user clicks "yes", ZeroNet will unzip the folder and place it into the plugins folder automatically.

THe only other thing that needs to be handled is restarting of zeronet, and perhaps some metadata with a signature to know where the plugin is coming from (e.g. who created it, etc.)

Also, ZeroNet is written in python, so we can have it work for all platforms, not just Linux.

> [quantumworld](#comment_315_1AdWXZdPUimpXoGNXUBde2CHR7gLf4onxE): We also want to include an uninstall option as well.  Just incase a plug in causes problems, or the user does not want to use that program as well. There needs to be a plug in manager of some kind. 1550266119_131Seivv6aH8vnohPmYPcPwPfZ1a5.body:
It should be noted:
1.) Optional/Big files are **not** counted in the normal limit. The normal limit usually only applies to your data.json file - which is where the video/file *information* (not the video/file itself) is stored (in the case of a video/files sharing zites) or comments, posts, etc. (in the case of social networking zites). I believe there may be another limiting setting zite owners can use specifically for optional/big files. But I don't think it's very needed as the optional files are never *automatically* downloaded (which is the main reason why the file size limit exists in the first place).

2.) The file limit is there to make sure you don't upload a file or make your content so big as to harm other peers of the zite (by using up large amounts of space on their hard drive). And this is especially important when user updates are automatically propagated to peers. It also helps prevent spam by setting a limit to the amount of possible space (and therefore spam) allowed to be used - which then requires the admin/owner of the zite to manually increase the limit either for that user or for other users. Again, since optional files are not *automatically* downloaded by peers (they must instead manually download optional files) - it makes no sense that this normal file size limit be applied to big files.

3.) The reason you get these two "contradictory" messages is because there's a difference between *uploading* to the zite and *signing and publishing* the zite. Zites are stored on your hard drive. You can easily "upload" files to a zite by just dragging and dropping files into the zite's folder. This is what the Upload feature of a zite does - it just copies the file you give it to your user's folder under the zite. **However,** while the zite will locally see/use this new information, you still have to **publish** your updates to other peers of this zite, so that they have the information also. *This* is where the file size limits come in. You can't sign and publish unless you are below the file size limit. This is to protect other peers, as stated before. So... you can upload successfully to the zite, but you cannot publish unless you are below the file size limit.

Of course, it would be good that all of these zites would detect whether you are going to go over the limit *before* the upload so that we can say the upload fails and there's no contradictory message. This also happens to be the reason why we get these contradictory messages in the first place. These zites upload first, then sign and publish - where ZeroNet checks the filesize limit during publish. So we're checking filesize limit **after** you've already uploaded to the zite.

1552767554_1L4dZcDF2maSKHDy788yhxpYnBWnX.body:
The fileserver port is different from the ui server port. The ui server port is *local only* and is what gives the html pages to your browser from the local filesystem (the UI server is an HTTP server)

The fileserver port is used to transfer files to/from other peers.

1555185007_1LiBAqfmPSAEhoFj2fM3iMEZe5uzZ.body:
Moore's law is not BS, it's an actual thing - but don't let the word "law" confuse you (It's not an actual law, it's just a statistical observation). **The person who created moore's law didn't think it would even last as long as it had**, which is why people, for some odd reason, think that it will continue - that computers will continue to get faster (in the way described by moore's law) - which makes absolutely no sense imo considering that we're already doing stuff at an atomical level and electricity requires *electrons* which are part of atoms.

So, yes, "Moore's Law", imo, **will end** eventually - and we're already seeing increases in speed and decreases in sizes peak off. I don't know if it will be in 2020 or not, but it will end eventually.

> [blazingeye](#comment_13_16eEwa5Fc9xKJWFQHBb9yNXPSmvuAu8aKd): photonics 

I've never heard of photonics. Thanks for mentioning that.

I was mostly saying that the **original** concept of Moore's law isn't quite BS - but the *interpretation* of it kinda is.

1555521255_1ME9gwj9Exp9cBbuSxxr1mEiySEjm.body:
> [anonuser1](#comment_1_1KCMNR9SKmNwjcTosGBGJsLkjLHtYz2h5k): Just a reminder: You can't upload something on ZeroNet if there's no one to download it, and in order for your site to be online there has to always be one person with the data and seeding it, ZeroNet looks a lot like BitTorrent.

You worded this a little weirdly imo, so I'm going to add to what you said a bit.
For others: You can't "Upload" to ZeroNet in the *traditional sense* (because ZeroNet is not a client-server model, it's p2p). So by "Uploading", all you are doing is allowing other peers to get the file from you. So, if there are no other peers, as long as you are online, then people can get it from you. You only need this until one other person downloads the file from you.

1555759517_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2.body:
> [robione](#comment_224_1DoVPxFrQCDb3grC8Nsn6aACed9o2oiumX):
>  like selecting which part of the screen to stream via the mouse

This isn't possible - we utilize the browser's MediaRecorder and MediaStream API - so it's up to the browser to allow this.

But, what we can do is support other recording software like OBS.

> [robione](#comment_226_1DoVPxFrQCDb3grC8Nsn6aACed9o2oiumX): ok, my suggestion still makes it easier to "select" the size of the final viewing size, right?

We can just have a select box for typical resolutions. Btw, the resolution you choose is also essentially the quality of the video. Basically, the resolution is the **output** size - it's what the browser will downsize (or you can upsize/upscale the output, I suppose) the recording to before it's broadcasted over the network.
